title: Genesis Chapter 1 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Genesis chapter 1 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Genesis Chapter 1 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Genesis Chapter 1.

questions.question: According to Genesis 1:1, what did God create in the beginning?
questions.correctAnswer: Heaven and the earth
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:1 states that in the beginning God created the heaven and the earth.

questions.question: What was upon the face of the deep before creation began according to Genesis 1:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Darkness
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:2 says darkness was upon the face of the deep before God began creation.

questions.question: In Genesis 1:3, what did God say?
questions.correctAnswer: Let there be light
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:3 records God saying, 'Let there be light.'

questions.question: What did God call the light and the darkness in Genesis 1:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Day and Night
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:5 states God called the light Day, and the darkness Night.

questions.question: What did God create to divide the waters according to Genesis 1:6?
questions.correctAnswer: Firmament
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:6 says God said, 'Let there be a firmament in the midst of the waters, and let it divide the waters from the waters.'

questions.question: True or False: Genesis 1:10 states that God called the dry land Earth and the gathering of waters Seas.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:10 clearly states God called the dry land Earth and the gathering together of the waters Seas.

questions.question: According to Genesis 1:11, what did God command the earth to bring forth?
options: Grass, herb yielding seed, and fruit trees
questions.correctAnswer: Grass, herb yielding seed, and fruit trees
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:11 commands the earth to bring forth grass, herbs yielding seed, and fruit trees yielding fruit.

questions.question: What were the two great lights God made according to Genesis 1:16?
options: The greater light to rule the day and the lesser light to rule the night
questions.correctAnswer: The greater light to rule the day and the lesser light to rule the night
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:16 states God made two great lights: the greater light to rule the day, and the lesser light to rule the night.

questions.question: True or False: According to Genesis 1:21, God created every living creature that moveth in the waters and every winged fowl.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:21 says God created great whales and every living creature that moveth in the waters, and every winged fowl after his kind.

questions.question: What blessing did God give to the creatures of the waters and fowl in Genesis 1:22?
options: Be fruitful, multiply, and fill the waters and earth
questions.correctAnswer: Be fruitful, multiply, and fill the waters and earth
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:22 records God blessing them to be fruitful, multiply, and fill the waters and earth.

questions.question: According to Genesis 1:24, what kind of living creatures did God command the earth to bring forth?
options: Cattle, creeping things, and beasts of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: Cattle, creeping things, and beasts of the earth
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:24 states God commanded the earth to bring forth cattle, creeping things, and beasts after their kind.

questions.question: Who did God create in His own image according to Genesis 1:27?
questions.correctAnswer: Man
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:27 says God created man in His own image, male and female created He them.

questions.question: True or False: Genesis 1:28 instructs man to be fruitful, multiply, replenish the earth, and have dominion over all living things.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:28 commands man to be fruitful, multiply, replenish the earth, subdue it, and have dominion over living creatures.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Genesis 1:29: 'Behold, I have given you every herb bearing seed, which is upon the face of all the _______, and every tree, in the which is the fruit of a tree yielding seed; to you it shall be for meat.'
questions.correctAnswer: earth
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:29 says God gave herbs and fruit trees upon the face of all the earth for meat.

questions.question: What did God see about everything He made at the end of the sixth day according to Genesis 1:31?
questions.correctAnswer: It was very good
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:31 states God saw everything He had made and it was very good.

questions.question: According to Genesis 1:17, where did God set the two great lights?
options: In the firmament of the heaven
questions.correctAnswer: In the firmament of the heaven
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:17 says God set the two great lights in the firmament of the heaven to give light upon the earth.

medium.title: Genesis Chapter 1 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Genesis Chapter 1 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged by the chaos in their life and asks how to trust God’s order. Based on Genesis 1, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God brings order from chaos through His word and Spirit
Life is naturally chaotic and without purpose
We must create our own order by human effort
Chaos is a punishment from God
questions.correctAnswer: God brings order from chaos through His word and Spirit
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:1-2 shows the earth was formless and void with darkness, yet God’s Spirit moved over the waters and His word brought light and order (verses 3-5). This teaches that God’s power establishes order in chaos.

questions.question: How does Genesis 1 teach us about obedience and faith in God’s word through the act of creation?
options: God’s spoken word immediately brings results
Humans must create things by their own hands
questions.correctAnswer: God’s spoken word immediately brings results
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:3, 6, 9, 14 show God saying 'Let there be...' and it was so, demonstrating the power and faithfulness of God’s word that calls creation into existence.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by the responsibilities of family and work. What practical encouragement about stewardship and work ethic does Genesis 1 offer?
options: God entrusted man to govern and care for creation responsibly
Work is a curse and should be avoided
Only spiritual work matters, not physical labor
Humans must compete harshly for resources
questions.correctAnswer: God entrusted man to govern and care for creation responsibly
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:26-28 shows God giving humans dominion over the earth and commanding them to be fruitful and multiply, indicating a call to faithful stewardship and diligent work.

questions.question: How does Genesis 1 teach humility and contentment in our daily lives?
options: All creation was made good by God’s hand, so we can be content in His provision
We must strive endlessly to improve creation by our own strength
Only spiritual things matter; physical things are worthless
We should reject God’s creation as flawed
questions.correctAnswer: All creation was made good by God’s hand, so we can be content in His provision
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:10, 12, 18, 25, 31 repeatedly say God saw creation was good or very good, teaching us to appreciate and be content with God’s provision in life.

questions.question: A new believer struggles with sharing their faith. What biblical insight from Genesis 1 encourages evangelism and witnessing?
options: God created humans in His image to rule and represent Him on earth
Faith is a private matter and should not be shared
Only priests and pastors should witness
Creation is separate from the Gospel message
questions.correctAnswer: God created humans in His image to rule and represent Him on earth
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:26-27 emphasizes humans made in God’s image with authority, implying a calling to reflect God’s character and share His truth with others.

questions.question: How does Genesis 1 encourage prayer and personal devotion in the life of a believer?
options: God’s creative word models the power of speaking and listening to God
Prayer is unnecessary if we work hard
Only communal worship matters, not personal devotion
God does not respond to prayers
questions.correctAnswer: God’s creative word models the power of speaking and listening to God
questions.explanation: The pattern of God speaking creation into being (Genesis 1:3, 6, 9) models the power of God’s word and encourages personal communication with God through prayer.

questions.question: True or False: Genesis 1 teaches that God’s creation includes a clear distinction between day and night to establish order and rhythm in life.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:4-5 and 14-19 describe God dividing light from darkness and creating day and night, establishing a rhythm that governs time and life.

questions.question: True or False: According to Genesis 1, humans are created last and have no responsibility over the rest of creation.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:26-28 clearly states that humans are made in God’s image and given dominion over fish, birds, cattle, and the earth, implying responsibility and stewardship.

questions.question: A parent is teaching their child about God’s provision. According to Genesis 1, what truth about God’s generosity should be shared?
options: God provided every seed-bearing herb and fruit tree for food
Humans must hunt and gather without God’s help
Food is scarce and must be fought for
Only animals were given food by God
questions.correctAnswer: God provided every seed-bearing herb and fruit tree for food
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:29-30 states God gave seed-bearing plants and fruit trees to humans and green herbs to animals for food, showing God’s generous provision.

questions.question: How does Genesis 1 instruct us about humility and the value of all creation, including animals and plants?
options: God saw every living thing He made as good, highlighting the value of all creation
Only humans have value; animals and plants are insignificant
Creation is inherently evil and should be controlled harshly
Plants and animals are enemies to humans
questions.correctAnswer: God saw every living thing He made as good, highlighting the value of all creation
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:10, 12, 18, 21, 25 and 31 repeatedly mention God saw His creation as good, teaching respect and humility toward all life.

questions.question: How does Genesis 1 teach perseverance through trials using the creation days as a pattern?
options: God’s work was done steadily day by day, showing the value of patient progress
Creation happened all at once with no process
Trials are a sign of God’s displeasure
Only instant results are valuable to God
questions.correctAnswer: God’s work was done steadily day by day, showing the value of patient progress
questions.explanation: Genesis 1 repeatedly notes 'And the evening and the morning were the [nth] day' (verses 5, 8, 13, 19, 23, 31), illustrating steady, patient work and perseverance.

questions.question: A believer wants to serve others in their church community. What aspect of Genesis 1 encourages serving and stewardship?
options: Humans are made in God’s image and given responsibility to manage and care for creation
Service is optional and unrelated to faith
God created humans to live only for themselves
Only clergy are called to serve others
questions.correctAnswer: Humans are made in God’s image and given responsibility to manage and care for creation
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:26-28 shows humans created in God’s image and entrusted with dominion, implying a calling to responsible stewardship and serving others.

questions.question: In Genesis 1:27, it says God created man in His own image, male and female. How does this teach biblical wisdom for marriage and family life?
options: Marriage reflects God’s image through male and female partnership
Men and women are unrelated in God’s plan
Family is a human invention, not from God
Only one gender is made in God’s image
questions.correctAnswer: Marriage reflects God’s image through male and female partnership
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:27 shows both male and female are created in God’s image, highlighting the divine design for marriage and family unity.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Genesis 1, God made two great lights; the greater to rule the ____, and the lesser to rule the ____.
questions.correctAnswer: day; night
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:16 states God made the greater light to rule the day and the lesser light to rule the night, establishing order and time.

questions.question: How does Genesis 1 encourage gratitude in believers regarding God’s creation?
options: God saw everything He made as very good and blessed them
Creation is flawed, so gratitude is unnecessary
Humans should be grateful only for spiritual blessings
Gratitude is not related to creation
questions.correctAnswer: God saw everything He made as very good and blessed them
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:31 says God saw everything He had made was very good, encouraging believers to be grateful for God’s perfect provision.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to doubt God’s goodness during hardships. Based on Genesis 1, what truth would you share to help them persevere?
options: God’s creation was declared very good, showing His perfect goodness from the start
God does not care about earthly life
Creation is random and without purpose
questions.correctAnswer: God’s creation was declared very good, showing His perfect goodness from the start
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:31 emphasizes God’s declaration that creation was very good, affirming His consistent goodness even in trials.

hard.title: Genesis Chapter 1 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Genesis Chapter 1.

questions.question: What Hebrew word is used in Genesis 1:1 to describe God's act of creation, and what is its significance in biblical theology?
questions.correctAnswer: Bara
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:1 uses the Hebrew word 'bara' which denotes a divine creation ex nihilo, a creation out of nothing, highlighting God's unique creative power distinct from human making ('asah').

questions.question: How does the division of light and darkness in Genesis 1:4 reflect the literary device of parallelism seen elsewhere in Scripture?
questions.correctAnswer: It establishes order from chaos
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:4's division of light from darkness is a classic example of parallelism that establishes cosmic order from primordial chaos, a theme echoed in Psalms and Isaiah.

questions.question: In Genesis 1:6-8, the 'firmament' is created to divide waters. What is the ancient Near Eastern cultural context of this concept?
options: A solid dome separating waters above and below
questions.correctAnswer: A solid dome separating waters above and below
questions.explanation: The 'firmament' (Hebrew 'raqia') reflects ancient Near Eastern cosmology where the sky was viewed as a solid dome holding back celestial waters, contrasting with pagan myths of chaotic waters.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage explicitly references the creation of man in God's image as described in Genesis 1:27?
questions.correctAnswer: James 3:9
questions.explanation: James 3:9 refers to mankind being made in the likeness of God, directly connecting to Genesis 1:27's teaching on the divine image of humanity.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'And God saw that it was good' repeated in Genesis 1, especially in verse 10?
options: It affirms the moral and aesthetic goodness of creation
It introduces the concept of sin
It signals the end of creation
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms the moral and aesthetic goodness of creation
questions.explanation: In Genesis 1:10 and throughout the chapter, 'God saw that it was good' underscores creation's inherent goodness, countering ancient myths of a chaotic or evil material world.

questions.question: How does the structure of the six days of creation in Genesis 1 reflect a chiastic literary pattern?
options: Days 1-3 create realms, and Days 4-6 fill them
questions.correctAnswer: Days 1-3 create realms, and Days 4-6 fill them
questions.explanation: Genesis 1 follows a chiastic structure where Days 1-3 form the creation of domains (light/darkness, sky/waters, land/vegetation) and Days 4-6 fill these domains with inhabitants (sun/moon/stars, birds/fish, animals/humans).

questions.question: In Genesis 1:14, the lights in the firmament are said to serve as signs for seasons, days, and years. What does this indicate about the ancient Israelite understanding of time?
options: Time is measured by celestial bodies
Time is controlled by pagan gods
questions.correctAnswer: Time is measured by celestial bodies
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:14 reflects the ancient Israelite view that celestial bodies govern the calendar and seasons, essential for religious festivals and agricultural cycles.

questions.question: What typological foreshadowing is found in the creation of the 'greater light to rule the day' and the 'lesser light to rule the night' in Genesis 1:16?
options: Christ as the light of the world
The giving of the Law at Sinai
questions.correctAnswer: Christ as the light of the world
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:16's lights foreshadow Christ, the ultimate light who rules spiritual darkness, as referenced in John 8:12 and 1 John 1:5.

questions.question: True or False: Genesis 1:2 describes the earth as 'without form, and void,' indicating a chaotic state before God's ordering.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:2 depicts the earth as 'tohu va bohu' (without form and void), representing a chaotic, unstructured state before God's creative ordering.

questions.question: According to Genesis 1:26, what is the scope of man's dominion given by God, and how does this reflect ancient covenantal themes?
options: Over fish, fowl, cattle, earth, and every creeping thing
questions.correctAnswer: Over fish, fowl, cattle, earth, and every creeping thing
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:26 grants man dominion over all earth's creatures, paralleling ancient Near Eastern kingly grants of authority, reflecting a covenantal stewardship role under God.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'Let us make man in our image' in Genesis 1:26, particularly the plural pronoun 'us'?
options: It suggests a divine council or trinitarian hint
It refers to angels creating man
It is a plural of majesty
questions.correctAnswer: It suggests a divine council or trinitarian hint
questions.explanation: The plural 'us' in Genesis 1:26 has been interpreted as God speaking to a heavenly court or as an early indication of the Trinity, emphasizing the communal nature of divine creation.

questions.question: How does the creation of plants bearing seed 'after their kind' in Genesis 1:11 relate to ancient Near Eastern agricultural practices?
options: It emphasizes the order and reliability of nature
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the order and reliability of nature
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:11's emphasis on plants yielding seed 'after their kind' reflects the importance of stable agricultural cycles for sustenance and covenantal blessing in ancient Near Eastern culture.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominently demonstrated by the repeated phrase 'And the evening and the morning were the nth day' in Genesis 1?
questions.correctAnswer: Refrain
questions.explanation: The repeated phrase acts as a refrain providing rhythmic structure and marking the completion of each creation day, a common literary device in Hebrew poetry and narrative.

questions.question: According to Genesis 1:31, how does the author's conclusion about creation's goodness contribute to the theological theme of the chapter?
options: It affirms creation's perfection and divine approval
It introduces the fall of man
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms creation's perfection and divine approval
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:31 states everything was 'very good,' reinforcing a theological theme of a perfect creation intentionally designed and approved by God.

questions.question: True or False: In Genesis 1:21, the creation of 'great whales' and 'every living creature' reflects the Hebrew word 'tanninim,' which has mythological connotations in the ancient Near East.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The Hebrew term 'tanninim' in Genesis 1:21, often translated as 'great sea creatures' or 'whales,' has parallels to mythological sea monsters, which the biblical text reinterprets as part of God's ordered creation.

theological.title: Genesis Chapter 1 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Genesis Chapter 1 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Genesis 1, what is the theological significance of God creating man in His own image?
options: Man has inherent dignity and dominion over creation
Man is a divine being equal to God
Man was created to be a servant without authority
Man was created without a soul
questions.correctAnswer: Man has inherent dignity and dominion over creation
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:26-27 teaches that man is made in God's image, signifying inherent dignity and authority to rule over creation. This reflects the biblical doctrine of Imago Dei, affirmed also in James 3:9, Colossians 3:10, and Psalm 8:5-8, highlighting mankind's unique role and value in God's design.

questions.question: What does Genesis 1 reveal about the nature of God’s creative word?
options: God creates by speaking, demonstrating sovereign authority
God creates through human effort and cooperation
Creation is accidental without divine plan
Creation is a result of chaos without order
questions.correctAnswer: God creates by speaking, demonstrating sovereign authority
questions.explanation: Throughout Genesis 1 (e.g., verses 3, 6, 9, 14), God creates simply by speaking, showing His sovereign power over all things. This is consistent with Psalm 33:6, Hebrews 11:3, and John 1:1-3, which affirm God’s word as powerful and effective in creation.

questions.question: Which day of creation did God declare 'very good' according to Genesis 1?
questions.correctAnswer: The sixth day
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:31 declares that after creating man and all living creatures on the sixth day, God saw everything as 'very good.' This underscores the perfection of creation before the Fall, consistent with Ecclesiastes 7:29 and Matthew 19:4 emphasizing original goodness.

questions.question: What role does the Spirit of God play in creation as described in Genesis 1?
options: The Spirit moves upon the waters, indicating active involvement
The Spirit is silent and uninvolved
The Spirit creates only the heavens
The Spirit commands the angels to create
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit moves upon the waters, indicating active involvement
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:2 states that the Spirit of God moved upon the face of the waters before creation fully took form, showing the Spirit’s active presence and power. This aligns with Job 33:4, Psalm 104:30, and John 3:5, which describe the Spirit’s creative and life-giving role.

questions.question: In Genesis 1, how is the creation of light theologically significant?
options: Light symbolizes God's order and presence over chaos
Light was created last as a minor element
Light is described only as physical, without spiritual meaning
Light and darkness are equal forces
questions.correctAnswer: Light symbolizes God's order and presence over chaos
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:3-4 introduces light at the beginning, separating it from darkness and establishing order. Light represents God’s presence and life, consistent with John 1:4-5, 1 John 1:5, and Isaiah 9:2, which affirm God as light overcoming darkness.

questions.question: What does Genesis 1 teach about the created order of the heavens and the earth?
options: God created heavens and earth distinct and purposeful
Earth was created before the heavens
Heavens and earth are equal and eternal
questions.correctAnswer: God created heavens and earth distinct and purposeful
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:1 affirms that God created both heavens and earth at the beginning, establishing a purposeful cosmos. This is foundational to biblical cosmology, supported by Nehemiah 9:6, Isaiah 45:18, and Colossians 1:16 highlighting God's sovereign design.

questions.question: How does Genesis 1 describe God's evaluation of creation?
options: God repeatedly saw creation as 'good' and finally 'very good'
God saw creation as flawed and incomplete
questions.correctAnswer: God repeatedly saw creation as 'good' and finally 'very good'
questions.explanation: Throughout Genesis 1 (e.g., verses 4, 10, 12, 18, 21, 25, 31), God evaluates His work as good, culminating in 'very good' after making man. This affirms the inherent goodness of creation, echoed in Psalm 104:24 and Romans 1:20 about God’s handiwork.

questions.question: What does the creation of the 'two great lights' in Genesis 1 signify?
options: God’s sovereign rule over day and night
The lights were made by angels
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereign rule over day and night
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:16-18 describes the greater and lesser lights ruling day and night, emphasizing God’s control over time and natural order. This theme is consistent with Psalm 74:16-17 and Jeremiah 31:35 affirming God’s governance over celestial bodies.

questions.question: What is the significance of God’s command to be 'fruitful and multiply' in Genesis 1?
options: It establishes humanity’s mandate to fill the earth
It applies only to plants, not animals or humans
It is a suggestion, not a command
questions.correctAnswer: It establishes humanity’s mandate to fill the earth
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:28 and 22 show God's blessing and command to multiply and fill the earth, highlighting the cultural mandate. This is foundational for human stewardship and mission, supported by Psalm 127:3-5 and Matthew 28:19's Great Commission.

questions.question: According to Genesis 1, what is provided as food for humans and animals?
options: Herbs bearing seed and fruit trees for humans; green herbs for animals
questions.correctAnswer: Herbs bearing seed and fruit trees for humans; green herbs for animals
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:29-30 states God gave seed-bearing plants and fruit trees for human food and green herbs for animals, indicating an original plant-based diet. This aligns with Isaiah 11:6-9, showing peace and provision in creation’s original state.

questions.question: What theological truth is revealed by God referring to Himself in the plural 'Let us make man' in Genesis 1?
options: It points to the plurality within the Godhead
It refers to God consulting angels
It implies many gods created man
questions.correctAnswer: It points to the plurality within the Godhead
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:26’s plural language 'Let us make man' indicates a complex unity in God, consistent with the doctrine of the Trinity. This is supported by John 1:1-3, Matthew 28:19, and 2 Corinthians 13:14, affirming one God in three persons.

questions.question: How does Genesis 1 depict the relationship between creation and God’s glory?
options: Creation reveals God’s power and goodness
Creation is independent of God’s glory
questions.correctAnswer: Creation reveals God’s power and goodness
questions.explanation: Genesis 1 portrays creation as a display of God's power, wisdom, and goodness (verses 1, 4, 10, 31). Romans 1:20 and Psalm 19:1 similarly teach that creation reveals God’s invisible attributes and glory to all people.

questions.question: Why is the division of light from darkness important in Genesis 1?
options: It establishes order and separates good from chaos
It shows light and darkness are equal gods
It was an accident without purpose
questions.correctAnswer: It establishes order and separates good from chaos
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:4-5 shows God dividing light from darkness, initiating cosmic order. This theme is echoed in Isaiah 45:7 where God creates light and darkness, establishing His control over chaos and evil.

questions.question: What does Genesis 1 teach about the origin of life in the waters and skies?
options: God created living creatures in water and air on the fifth day
Life in water and air was created before earth
God created only land animals first
questions.correctAnswer: God created living creatures in water and air on the fifth day
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:20-23 describes God creating aquatic life and birds on the fifth day, showing intentional divine origin of life. This is consistent with Job 12:10 and Psalm 148:7-10 affirming God’s creative authority over all living things.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'firmament' in Genesis 1?
options: It separates the waters above from the waters below and is called Heaven
It is a solid dome trapping waters
It is an illusion without real function
It is a place where angels reside exclusively
questions.correctAnswer: It separates the waters above from the waters below and is called Heaven
questions.explanation: Genesis 1:6-8 explains God’s creation of the firmament to divide waters and calling it Heaven, showing God’s ordering of the cosmos. This imagery is paralleled in Psalm 104:2-3 and Ezekiel 1:22-26, describing God’s sovereign structure over creation.

questions.question: How does Genesis 1 support the doctrine of God’s providence over creation?
options: God actively creates and sustains all things by His word
Creation is left to chance without divine care
Creation is controlled by natural forces alone
questions.correctAnswer: God actively creates and sustains all things by His word
questions.explanation: Genesis 1 shows God’s deliberate creative acts by speaking, indicating ongoing providence. Hebrews 1:3, Colossians 1:17, and Psalm 104:27-30 affirm God’s continuous sustaining of creation.
